title: Softbank's Arora: U.S. companies are 'priced for perfection'
text:
TechCrunch Disrupt, in San Francisco's Dogpatch neighborhood. (Photo: John Shinal, for USA TODAY)
6 CONNECT 62 TWEET 4 LINKEDIN 1 COMMENT EMAIL MORE SAN FRANCISCO — Softbank President Nikesh Arora is looking to make huge investments in technology companies right now – just not in the U.S.
The former chief business officer of Google, who spent a decade at the search giant and made millions from its surging stock price, is writing big checks all over the globe.
His new job is to “acquire more assets…more technology companies around the world” for Softbank, the Japanese conglomerate founded 35 years ago by investor Masayoshi Son.
Most of the checks Softbank is writing for these deals “are between $100 million and $1 billion,” Arora told an audience gathered here for the second day of the TechCrunch DisruptSF conference.
For example, Softbank in June poured $1 billion into Korean e-commerce company Coupang, which is attacking a market worth $15 billion, Arora says.
Last October, in one of the first big stakes Softbank took after Arora came on board, the company invested $627 million in Snapdeal, an Indian online retailer.
In August, Softbank joined another $500 million investment round in Snapdeal, in a round led by Chinese e-commerce giant Alibaba.
People walk in the headquarters campus of Alibaba in Hangzhou, China. (Photo: Crab Hu, European Pressphoto Agency)
The company also invested $250 million in GrabTaxi, a ride-sharing service in Malaysia, in January.
Yet one country has been noticeably absent of late from those that are home to very large Softbank investments: the U.S.
The reason, Arora says, is too much froth in stock valuations here.
“We think some of the valuations in the U.S. market are a bit robust,” Arora said from the stage. “They’re priced to perfection, and no one executes perfectly.”
Arora sees a shakeout coming that will result in better bargains among U.S. companies several years from now.
“We think we’ll have the chance to invest in premium U.S. companies in three-to-five years” at lower valuations, he said.
Softbank shares are under water this year, and a sharp drop in the value of its huge stakes in Alibaba and Sprint may be one reason why Arora is leery of U.S. valuations.
Softbank Group shares are down 12% in Tokyo this year, while Softbank Technology shares are down 4%.
Softbank owns one-third of Alibaba, whose shares have come crashing back to earth after its high-flying IPO a year ago.
The value of Softbank’s stake in Alibaba is “smaller now than it was a year ago,” Arora said wryly. “But we think it has huge potential.”
The most notable investment Softbank has made in the U.S. this year was an $87 million cash infusion it gave to Sprint in August.
Softbank owns roughly 80% of the wireless carrier, which has been hurt as the cost of consumer phone plans have come down.

Since Softbank closed its $21.6 billion Sprint investment in July, 2013, the phone company’s shares are down 20%.
